book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Do not be distracted by a possible finesse
solution_line: The main point – Do not be distracted by a possible finesse. You are sure to make the contract if you play the ace and queen of clubs. You have nine top tricks and a club ruff in the West hand will bring the total to ten. The Scots made the contract of 3NT without any problems: +400 for EW. You played the ace and queen of clubs: +420 = +1 IMP. You tried to take a club finesse: –10 IMP.
result_comparison: You cashed the ace of clubs; +620 = +12 IMP. If not: no swing.
additional_notes: The pool of points to win is 45 IMP = 24-6 VP. Your next match is against Scotland.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Use safety play, but prudently not as a routine play
solution_line: The main point – Use safety play, but prudently not as a routine play. You have already encountered a similar problem (102). Then you played a small club to the nine in the dummy. This the beauty of bridge – everything depends on the circumstances. In this case such a move would be quite wrong because it would allow South to make a damaging lead though your queen of hearts. Order of play: 1-2. Duck the spade and win the spade continuation. 3-4. Play the queen of clubs. North wins the queen with the ace and continues with spades. 5. Now it is time to play a small club to the nine. The Scots made 3NT: +400 for EW. Queen of clubs: no swing. You played it differently: –10 IMP.
result_comparison: The Scots made 3NT: +400 for EW. Queen of clubs: no swing. You played it differently: –10 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
opening_lead: North plays clubs three times. South produces the ace on the third trick
key_insight: Protect your trumps from a force and preserve communications
solution_line: The main point – Protect your trumps from a force and preserve communications. Order of play: 3-4. Ruff the third round of clubs and play a heart to the ten. Even if the finesse loses, the queen of hearts in dummy will prevent a further force in clubs. Closed room – Contract 3NT, one down: +100 for NS. A heart to the ten: +650 for EW = +13 IMP. Otherwise: no swing.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, one down: +100 for NS. A heart to the ten: +650 for EW = +13 IMP. Otherwise: no swing.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Calculate which combinations you can handle successfully
solution_line: The main point – Calculate which combinations you can handle successfully. Order of play: 2-3. Cash the ace and king of spades. If the queen falls, play safe for three club tricks – ace and small to ♣9. If the queen does not fall, you need four club tricks. The routine play would be a club to the king and finesse a club. But not this time. Single queen of clubs with North will not help but with South – yes. 4-5. A diamond to the ace and a low club, underleading your king! In this case you may slightly increase your chances of making the game and it costs you nothing. After an unsuccessful club finesse the opponents would cash two spade tricks and two diamond tricks – still only one off. The Scots went one off in 3NT: +50 for NS. You played it accurately: +10 IMP. If not: – no swing.
result_comparison: The Scots went one off in 3NT: +50 for NS. You played it accurately: +10 IMP. If not: – no swing.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Do not allow the defenders to put you to an early guess
solution_line: The main point – Do not allow the defenders to put you to an early guess. Order of play: 1-6. Eliminate clubs and draw trumps. 7-8. Play the ace of hearts and a low heart to the jack. You will make it with a doubleton heart king on either side, when hearts break 3-3 or finally you can always try the diamond finesse. If instead you finesse the king of hearts, South will win with the king and play a diamond. You will have to guess whether to finesse in diamonds before you know if hearts are 3-3. Closed room – Contract 6♣: +980 for EW. You played ace and a small heart: no swing. You played it differently: –14 IMP.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 6♣: +980 for EW. You played ace and a small heart: no swing. You played it differently: –14 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Make the dangerous opponent pay a high price for gaining the lead
solution_line: The main point – Make the dangerous opponent pay a high price for gaining the lead. Duck ♣10. You will then have a chance to establish a club trick before South can play through your heart holding. If South overtakes with the queen you can set up two club winners for two discards. Closed room – Contract 4♠, lead ♠10, +620 for Scotland. You ducked ♣10: no swing. If not: –12 IMP.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♠, lead ♠10, +620 for Scotland. You ducked ♣10: no swing. If not: –12 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Exhaust one defender of the cards that could force you
solution_line: The main point – Exhaust one defender of the cards that could force you. Order of play: 2. Pitch a club. 3. Ruff the third round of spades. 4-7. Draw trumps in four rounds. 8. Finesse the king of clubs. South then has no spade to play. Closed room – Contract 5♣, +400 for EW. You discarded a club on the second spade: +420 = +1 IMP. You ruffed: –10 IMP.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 5♣, +400 for EW. You discarded a club on the second spade: +420 = +1 IMP. You ruffed: –10 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Play without unnecessary hesitation and do not make it easy for the defender to find a damaging move
solution_line: The main point – Play without unnecessary hesitation and do not make it easy for the defender to find a damaging move. Order of play: 1-2. Win the heart lead and play ♠10. The ten and not the jack! Maybe North will fall asleep and will not cover with the queen. He may also worry that his partner has a singleton jack. The Scots stopped in 2♠, +140 for EW. You played ♠10 (you knew this little trick): +420 = +7 IMP. If not: –5 IMP.
result_comparison: The Scots stopped in 2♠, +140 for EW. You played ♠10 (you knew this little trick): +420 = +7 IMP. If not: –5 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Let the opponents do your work for you
solution_line: The main point – Let the opponents do your work for you. Order of play: 1. Win the ace of spades. 2-4. Draw trumps in three rounds. 5-6. Play the ace and king of diamonds. 7. Exit in spades. The Scottish team made 4♠ after an accurate line of play. You played effectively: no swing. You played three rounds of diamonds yourself: –12 IMP.
result_comparison: The Scottish team made 4♠ after an accurate line of play. You played effectively: no swing. You played three rounds of diamonds yourself: –12 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: You know the manoeuvre in spades, it is a bit complicated. Duck the first spade.
solution_line: The main point – You know the manoeuvre in spades, it is a bit complicated. Order of play: 1. Duck a spade ruffing in the hand. 2-3. Cross to dummy with a club and play a heart. Now South faces a dilemma: a) if he ducks, you will establish a spade and discard your last heart. b) if instead he rises with the heart ace, you will have three discards for your diamonds (including one that you establish in spades). You ask why you need to duck the first spade? It is protect yourself from the opponent's good play. If you play an honour, South may hold up his ace and the whole scheme will be ruined. Closed room – Contract 3NT: +660 for EW. You ducked the first spade: +12 IMP. It did not occur to you: –13 IMP.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT: +660 for EW. You ducked the first spade: +12 IMP. It did not occur to you: –13 IMP.
additional_notes: A pool of points to win with Scotland: +44 IMP = 24-6 VP. In round 13 you will face a difficult team from England.
